clues.text:
"Henry IV, Part 2":
"He hath eaten me out of ____ and ____"

"Julius Caesar":
"____ tu, ____?"

"Henry VI, Part 2":
"The first thing we do, let's ____ all the ____"

"Romeo and Juliet":
"It is the ____, and Juliet is the ____"
clues.response: "It is the east, and Juliet is the sun"

clues.text: A double double blank, from "Macbeth": "____ is ____, and ____ is ____"
clues.response: "Fair is foul, and foul is fair"

clues.text: AKA permanent maxillary third molars, these teeth can help you chew, but about 85% of us will need to get them removed
In animals, arrector pili muscles raise hairs, making them look larger; in humans, they only cause this "fowl" effect
This more common name for your coccyx tells you what useless body part it once belonged to
Not only do men have nipples, they also have these accompanying glands that serve no male purpose
We can't use it to detect pheromones like other animals, but we have a vestigial version of Jacobson's organ in this body part
It's found in an idiom with "No... ands, or buts"
One of Santa's helpers, or a Keebler baker
Going back to the Bible, a minor drawback is sometimes likened to one of these "in the ointment"
Towards the rear of a ship
A dandy dude

rounds.comments: (Alex: These are words that contain their own synonyms. For example, if we gave you "masculine", the synonym would be "male". It's found inside "masculine".)

clues.text: Old Mother Hubbard found that the cupboard was this, not its kangaroo word "barren"
Some said the debutante "blossomed" at the ball; others used this word
You "indolent" lazybones! Stop being so this
You're safe to leave that precious item in my "charge", or in my this
She led him down the path to "destruction", aka the road to this

rounds.comments: (Alex: Clues from this season that were not selected before time ran out.)

clues.text: A saying about this empire's vastness in the 18th to the 20th century was that "the sun never sets" on it
Luke 6:13: Jesus "called unto him his disciples: and of them he chose twelve, whom also he named" these
In a 2019 movie this superhero punched an elderly woman on a train (but she had a really good reason)
In September 1882 thousands of workers held a march in NYC & this holiday was born
The subject of "A Beautiful Mind", in 2015 he won the Abel Prize for his work on partial differential equations
It's a one-word exclamation meaning "I give up!"
This type of vote made George Washington president of the Constitutional Convention
At the sushi bar, freshwater eel goes by this Japanese name
By definition, it's any mammal that has hooves
To move in waves

rounds.comments: (Alex: We're gonna give you a mashup of two popular musical groups, and you name them both in...)

clues.text:
Both Rock & Roll Hall of Famers:
Cheap Jam
Rage Against the Sabbath
clues.response: Rage Against the Machine and Black Sabbath

clues.text: Smashing Blowfish
clues.response: Smashing Pumpkins and Hootie and the Blowfish

clues.text: My Chemical Monkeys
clues.response: My Chemical Romance and Arctic Monkeys

clues.text: Cold War Springfield
clues.response: The Cold War Kids and Buffalo Springfield

clues.text: In ancient times it was known as Mare Hadriaticum
The ruins of Qumran, including some notable caves, overlook its northwest shore
The Bosporus Strait connects the Sea of Marmara with this other sea
The "Cradle to the Great Barrier Reef", it's home to some of the most diverse marine life in the world
The largest ice shelf in Antarctica lies at the head of this same-named sea
If I told you this province's flower was the dogwood, could you guess it? How about if it's the Pacific dogwood?
Quebec's motto is "Je me souviens", "I" do this
You can't sweep the category unless you know that this is the provincial sport of Saskatchewan
Of course this province's flag is basically the cross of St. Andrew with reverse colors
Alberta picked the lodgepole this as its provincial tree, as it supplied ties for the railroad
"City of Dreams" is Tyler Anbinder's epic history of 400 years of this U.S. metropolis' immigrant experience
Anne Applebaum's "Red Famine" is a history of this Soviet leader's oppression of Ukraine in the 1930s
1930s interviews with these people have been mined for books including "Life Under the 'Peculiar Institution'"
"Imperial Twilight" by Stephen Platt takes a look at the relations between Britain & this nation during the Opium Wars
A look at great historic clashes, Philip Sabin's "Lost Battles" includes this 490 B.C. battle the Persians lost to the Greeks
It's the most common written letter in French, too, but Georges Perec wrote the novel "La DIsparition" without using it
Diddy dropped it in 2005
The old East Coast accent like Katharine Hepburn's or William F. Buckley's was marked by dropping this letter
The Motion Picture Association of America abandoned this letter rating in 1990
It was one of the 3 original blood groups discovered in 1900 but got changed to O
Better known for his "Tales", in the 1390s he wrote a "Treatise on the Astrolabe"
Benjamin Bunny convinces this other Beatrix Potter bunny to go back to Mr. McGregor's garden
Homophonic last names of Samuel & Ben, whom Samuel wrote about in "Lives of the Poets"
This "Vanity Fair" author quarreled with Dickens but was able to "Makepeace" with him
